questions.question: Who founded Death Eater?

The “Death Eaters” are a fictional group from J.K. Rowling’s *Harry Potter* series.  
They were founded by **Tom Marvolo Riddle**, who later became known as **Lord Voldemort**. Riddle created the group as a cadre of loyal dark‑wizard supporters to carry out his plans for domination of the wizarding world.

questions.question: Which city did Pablo Picasso work in?
questions.system_answer:
Pablo Picasso’s artistic career spanned several major cities, each of which left a distinct imprint on his work:

| City | Period & Key Works | Why It Matters |
|------|--------------------|----------------|
| **Barcelona, Spain** | 1900‑1904 (early period) | Born in Málaga, Picasso moved to Barcelona at 14. He studied at the **School of Arts and Crafts** and produced his first major works, such as *“The Blue Room”* (1901) and *“The Old Guitarist”* (1903). |
| **Madrid, Spain** | 1904‑1905 | He attended the **Royal Academy of Fine Arts of San Fernando** and painted *“The Three Dancers”* (1905). |
| **Paris, France** | 1905‑1973 (most of his life) | After arriving in Paris in 1905, Picasso became a central figure of the **Cubist** movement. He worked in the **Montmartre** and **Montparnasse** districts, producing masterpieces such as *“Les Demoiselles d’Avignon”* (1907), *“Guernica”* (1937), and countless others. |
| **Algiers, Algeria** | 1940‑1942 | During WWII, he lived in Algiers and painted works influenced by North African motifs, e.g., *“The Three Dancers”* (1940). |
| **New York, USA** | 1947‑1948 | He spent a brief period in New York, where he painted *“The Old Guitarist”* (1948) and engaged with the burgeoning Abstract Expressionist scene. |
| **Barcelona again** | 1960s | He returned to Barcelona for a few years, creating works that reflected his mature style. |

**In short:** While Picasso worked in many places, **Paris** was the city where he spent the majority of his career and produced the bulk of his most famous works.

questions.question: Who founded Sōtō?
questions.system_answer: The Sōtō school of Zen Buddhism was founded by **Dōgen Zenji** (Japanese: Dōgen, 1200–1253). He established the school in Japan in the early 13th century, emphasizing the practice of shikantaza (“just sitting”) as the core of Zen practice.
